content: As I've been learning about presheaves and the co-Yoneda lemma, I've realized it's set up an interesting dichotomy between two ways of gluing objects in a category CCC. You can either take a colimit in CCC to get another object of CCC that acts like the objects in the diagram "glued together", or you could take the colimit in the presheaf category. This comes with the intuition of building up a space "locally modeled on" the objects of CCC that might not live in CCC itself. The reason this seems to be a dichotomy is because Yoneda embedding does not preserve colimits, so these two ways of gluing do not, on the surface, seem to correspond.

The reason I'm struggling with this is because there are situations where you have to choose between these options to do some sort of gluing you want, and it's not always obvious which choice to make. My question is: is there any general rule connecting these two ideas, and if so, what would be the conceptual underpinning (IE, in terms of what gluing is doing what). Maybe there's some formula to convert a colimit diagram in one setting into an "equivalent" one in the other setting?
This problem is one way to motivate the study of sheaves. Have a look at this article.

To expand on this: subcanonical Grothendieck topologies on the category CCC present ways of gluing objects of CCC that interpolate between the two above methods, with the trivial Grothendieck topology representing the presheaf category and its colimits and the canonical Grothendieck topology representing, I believe, a completion of CCC that preserves any [[universal colimits]] it already has.

And for your question as to a formula to convert: you convert a colimit in C^\widehat CC to one in CCC by taking the [[weighted colimit]] of the identity functor in CCC weighted by the presheaf. This weighted colimit will exist precisely if taking the colimit in CCC in the first place would have.

More generally, for any collection Φ\PhiΦ of colimits that exist in CCC, you can consider the full subcategory of the presheaf category C^\widehat{C}C consisting of those presheaves that preserve the colimits in Φ\PhiΦ (that is, take them to limits in Set). This is (assuming CCC and Φ\PhiΦ are small) a reflective subcategory of C^\widehat{C}C, hence complete and cocomplete, and the Yoneda embedding factors through it by a functor that preserves Φ\PhiΦ-colimits. It has a universal property as the free cocompletion of CCC subject to preservation of Φ\PhiΦ-colimits.
A very general version of this story appears as Section 4 of my paper with Lobbia.
I did not know that! Is there a description of C^\widehat{C}C when Φ\PhiΦ is the collection of all colimits that exist in CCC?
Do you mean C^\widehat{C}C, which doesn't depend on Φ\PhiΦ, or the full subcategory of the presheaf category C^\widehat{C}C consisting of those presheaves that preserve the colimits in Φ\PhiΦ?
Sorry, I meant a description of the full subcategory of C^\widehat{C}C whose objects are presheaves preserving all colimits
Older references include Kennison "On limit-preserving functors", and Freyd-Kelly "Categories of continuous functors I".
I don't think there is a description of C^Φ\widehat{C}_\PhiCΦ​ other than its definition, in general.
(Although I'm not sure what sort of "description" you wanted.)

Thanks for the references! I was wondering if these categories had a universal property like the fact that the whole category of presheaves is the free cocompletion (putting aside size issues). In the article "On limit-preserving functors", Kennison writes:

As Lambek points out this result implies that [A, Ens]inf is sup-complete and can be regarded as a nicely behaved completion of A°, the dual or opposite category of A.

Is this category [A, Ens]inf, which I think is C^Φ\widehat{C}_\PhiCΦ​ for CCC the opposite of A and Φ\PhiΦ the collection of all colimits, a completion with a universal property, for instance?

Mike Shulman said:

It has a universal property as the free cocompletion of CCC subject to preservation of Φ\PhiΦ-colimits.
I see, thanks

Nathan Corbyn said:

This problem is one way to motivate the study of sheaves. Have a look at this article.

James Deikun said:

To expand on this: subcanonical Grothendieck topologies on the category CCC present ways of gluing objects of CCC that interpolate between the two above methods

That's cool... I'd heard of sheaves in this use before but hadn't thought too much about it prior to now!

Mike Shulman said:

More generally, for any collection Φ\PhiΦ of colimits that exist in CCC, you can consider the full subcategory of the presheaf category C^\widehat{C}C consisting of those presheaves that preserve the colimits in Φ\PhiΦ (that is, take them to limits in Set). This is (assuming CCC and Φ\PhiΦ are small) a reflective subcategory of C^\widehat{C}C

But as a reflective subcategory of a presheaf category, isn't this just the same thing as sheafification? Unless somehow the resulting category isn't a topos, or the reflection isnt left exact, etc.

James Deikun said:

And for your question as to a formula to convert: you convert a colimit in C^\widehat CC to one in CCC by taking the [[weighted colimit]] of the identity functor in CCC weighted by the presheaf. This weighted colimit will exist precisely if taking the colimit in CCC in the first place would have.

That's interesting... my follow up to this would be about going the other way. Is there a weighted colimit formula to express a colimit in CCC within C^\widehat CC?

John Onstead said:

the resulting ... reflection isn't left exact

Bingo.
(And therefore the resulting category isn't a topos.)

Mike Shulman said:

Bingo.

Ah ok, that makes sense!

But as a left adjoint, the reflection from presheaves into this subcategory preserves colimits. So that leads to an interesting question. Let's say there was an object XXX of CCC that had a colimit representation in both CCC and C^\widehat{C}C (obviously different, since Yoneda does not preserve colimits). By the universal property of C^Φ\widehat{C}_{\Phi}CΦ​, as well as the fact that left adjoints preserve colimits, both of these colimit representations of XXX have incarnations in C^Φ\widehat{C}_{\Phi}CΦ​.
My question is then: what, if any, is the connection between them- do they ever converge, or are they seemingly parallel and independent colimit representations of XXX in this category?
Generally they'll be different.

Of course it depends on what "representations" you pick. For instance, there are in fact a few colimits that Yoneda does preserve, namely the [[absolute colimits]]. And if you choose a Φ\PhiΦ-colimit in CCC, then it would be preserved in C^Φ\widehat{C}_\PhiCΦ​. But if you choose an arbitrary colimit in CCC and an arbitrary one in C^Φ\widehat{C}_\PhiCΦ​ they might have totally different shapes even if they were both Φ\PhiΦ-colimits.
I see. It's certainly interesting that there's a setting where both kinds of colimit exist, but don't necessarily "talk to each other"!

I think I now have a good handle on how to "resolve" the fact that Yoneda does not preserve colimits on a mathematical level (IE, take the Φ\PhiΦ subcategory), and I even know how to go from colimits in the presheaf category back to a weighted colimit in the original category. But I still feel as if I am missing sort of a conceptual picture for this situation. That is, what, on a conceptual level, is the fundamental difference between gluing in a category versus in its presheaf category, especially if we are meant to interpret the representables in a presheaf category as the objects of the original category via the Yoneda embedding?

I don't know if this helps, but one analogy you can think about is the free group FGFGFG generated by the underlying set of a group GGG. There's an injection X→FXX\to FXX→FX for any set XXX, and so we can if we wish think of the generators inside FGFGFG as "being" the elements of GGG. But the multiplication in the group FGFGFG has nothing to do with the original multiplication in GGG; in particular the product of two generators is no longer a generator.
Yes, this analogy helps! Especially factoring in a discussion I had a while ago on here about the analogy between free algebraic objects on generators and the idea of free cocompletion.
